enhanced_grid.py

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 ## @package enhanced_grid 
00002 ## @brief Contains 2D and 3D Grid containers that supports extended slicing syntax.
00003 ## 
00004 # These classes are provided for rapid prototyping, the methods defined on them might be slow.
00005 # @code
00006 # grid1 = Grid3D(10, 10, 10, 0)
00007 # grid2 = Grid3D(10, 10, 10, 1)
00008 # grid1[0, 0, 0] = grid2[0, 0, 0]
00009 # grid1[0, 0, 2:6:2] = grid2[0, 0, 4:5]
00010 # grid1[0, 0, ...] = grid2[0, 0, ...]
00011 # grid1[0, ..., 0] = grid2[..., 0, 0]
00012 # grid1[..., ..., ...] = grid2[..., ...., ....]
00013 # @endcode
00014 #
00015 # Slicing does not copy elements - an auxiliary window container is created that delegates 
00016 # further operations to the underlying container.
00017 # Note that assignments to slices from the same object might not behave as espected. 
00018 # Parallel assignment also does not always work as expected.
00019 # For example:
00020 #@code
00021 # grid[..., 0], grid[..., 1] = grid[..., 1], grid[..., 0]
00022 #@endcode
00023 # does not correctly swop two rows, but the following does:
00024 #@code
00025 # grid[..., 0], grid[..., 1] = grid[..., 1].clone(), grid[..., 0].clone()
00026 #@endcode
00027 #Strictly speaking, it is necessary only to clone the one object,
00028 #but it is hard to remember which, so it is better to clone both (?).
00029 # 
00030 #@todo Implement a way to use copy containers instead of window containers
00031 
00032 from __future__ import division
00033 from random import randint
00034 from math import floor
00035 from math import ceil
00036 from array import array
00037 
00038 ##@brief A class that works just like a queue or a stack, except
00039 ## that a randomly selected element is returned. 
00040 ##
00041 # This class is useful for implementing algorithms that gather 
00042 # elements, and need to process them randomly. Something along the 
00043 # lines of:
00044 # 
00045 # @code
00046 # while not rqueue.empty():
00047 #   #generates 3 new elements to process
00048 #   for i in range(3): 
00049 #     rqueue.push(process(rqueue.pop())) 
00050 # @endcode
00051 class RandomQueue:
00052         ## Constructs a new empty RandomQueue
00053         def __init__(self):             
00054                 ## The internal list to store objects.
00055                 self.array = []
00056 
00057         ##Returns True if this RandomQueue is empty.    
00058         def empty(self):
00059                 return len(self.array) <= 0
00060         
00061         ## Push a new element into the RandomQueue.
00062         def push(self, x):
00063                 self.array.append(x)
00064         
00065         ## @brief Pops a randomly selected element from the queue. 
00066         ##
00067         # All elements can be selected equiprobably
00068         def pop(self):
00069                 n = len(self.array)
00070                 
00071                 if n <= 0:
00072                         raise IndexError('Cannot pop from emty container!')
00073                 elif n == 1:
00074                         return self.array.pop()
00075                 else:
00076                         i = randint(0, n - 1)
00077                         j = n - 1
00078                         self.array[i], self.array[j] =  self.array[j], self.array[i]
00079 
00080                 return self.array.pop()
00081 
00082 ## @brief Class that represents a 2D array. 
00083 ##
00084 # The following convenient syntax is supported:
00085 # @code
00086 # p = 2, 3 # a coordinate in the grid
00087 # grid[p] = 5
00088 # print grid[p] 
00089 # print grid[2, 3] 
00090 # @endcode
00091 #
00092 
00093 def signum(x):
00094         if x > 0:
00095                 return 1
00096         elif x < 0:
00097                 return -1
00098         else:
00099                 return 0
00100 
00101 ## Truncates a point to integer coordinates.
00102 def int_point_2d(p):
00103         x, y = p
00104         return int(x), int(y)
00105 
00106 ## Truncates a point to integer coordinates.
00107 def int_point_3d(p):
00108         x, y, z = p
00109         return int(x), int(y), int(z)
00110 
00111 # Every point in the sample set is represented with 
00112 # a 1 in th grid; all other points are represented with 0.
00113 # The returned grid is usefull for producing image data.
00114 def points_to_grid(points, dimensions):
00115         grid = Grid2D(dimensions, 0)
00116         
00117         for point in points:
00118                 grid[int_point_2d(point)] = 1
00119                 
00120         return grid
00121         
00122 ## Converts a list of points to a 3D grid. 
00123 
00124 # Every point in the sample set is represented with 
00125 # a 1 in th grid; all other points are represented with 0.
00126 # The returned grid is usefull for producing image data.
00127 def points_to_grid_3d(points, dimensions):
00128         grid = Grid3D(dimensions, 0)
00129         
00130         for point in points:
00131                 grid[int_point_3d(point)] = 1
00132                 
00133         return grid
00134 
00135 def make_grid_1d(width, initial_item=None):
00136         grid = [initial_item] * width
00137         
00138         return grid
00139 
00140 ## @brief Makes 2 list of lists.
00141 def make_grid_2d(width, height, initial_item=None):
00142         grid = [None] * width
00143                 
00144         for i in range(width):
00145                 grid[i] = [None] * height
00146                 
00147                 for j in range(height):
00148                         grid[i][j] = initial_item
00149                         
00150         return grid
00151 
00152 ## @brief Makes 2 list of lists.
00153 def make_grid_3d(width, height, depth, initial_item):
00154         grid = [None] * width
00155                 
00156         for i in range(width):
00157                 grid[i] = [None] * height
00158                 
00159                 for j in range(height):
00160                         grid[i][j] = [None] * depth
00161                         
00162                         for k in range(depth):
00163                                 grid[i][j][k] = initial_item
00164                                 
00165         return grid
00166 
00167 ## @brief Returns an range that can be used to iterate over 
00168 ## the slice of the container.
00169 #
00170 # The following snippets are equivalent
00171 #@code
00172 # s = slice(3, 18, 3)
00173 # for i in srange(s):
00174 #       print list[i]
00175 #@endcode
00176 #
00177 #@code
00178 # for item in list[s]:
00179 #       print item
00180 #@endcode
00181 def srange(s, length):
00182         if s == Ellipsis:
00183                 return range(length)
00184         else:
00185                 b, e, s = s.indices(length)
00186                 return range(b, e, s)
00187 
00188 ## @brief Returns true if s is a slice or an Ellipsis.
00189 def is_slice(s):
00190         return type(s) is slice or s == Ellipsis
00191 
00192 ## @brief Returns the number of elements this slice will return, provided the provided 
00193 ## primary is large enough.
00194 def slice_len(s, length):
00195         if s == Ellipsis:
00196                 return length
00197                 
00198         b, e, s, = s.indices(length)
00199 
00200         tmp = int(ceil((e - b) / s))
00201         
00202         if tmp < 0:
00203                 return 0
00204         else:
00205                 return min(tmp, length)
00206         
00207         
00208         
00209         
00210         
00211         if s.stop > s.start and s.step > 0:
00212                 return (s.stop - s.start) // s.step
00213         elif s.stop < s.start and s.step < 0:
00214                 return (s.start - s.stop) // -s.step
00215         else:
00216                 return 0
00217 
00218 ## @brief Returns a slice that is equivalent to the two slices combined.
00219 ##
00220 # The following snippets are equivalent:
00221 #@code
00222 # list[s1][s2]
00223 #@endcode
00224 
00225 #@code
00226 # list[slice_mul(s1, s2)]
00227 #@endcode
00228 def slice_mul(slice1, slice2, length):
00229         if type(slice2) is int:
00230                 if type(slice1) is type(Ellipsis):
00231                         return slice2
00232                 b1, e1, s1 = slice1.indices(length)
00233                 s2 = slice2
00234                 if s2 < 0:
00235                         s2 += length
00236                 if s2 < 0:
00237                         s2 = 0          
00238                 return b1 + s2*s1
00239         elif type(slice2) is slice:
00240                 if type(slice1) is type(Ellipsis):
00241                         return slice2
00242                 else:
00243                         b1, e1, s1 = slice1.indices(length)
00244                         b2, e2, s2 = slice2.indices(length)                     
00245                         b = b1 + b2*s1
00246                         s = s1*s2
00247                         e = min(b1 + e2*s1, e1)
00248                         
00249                         if e < 0 and s < 0:
00250                                 return slice(b, None, s)
00251                         else:
00252                                 return slice(b, e,  s)
00253                         
00254                         
00255                         
00256                         b = slice1.start + slice2.start*slice1.step
00257                         s = slice1.step*slice2.step
00258                         return slice(b, min(slice1.start + slice2.stop*slice1.step, slice1.stop), s)
00259         elif slice2 == Ellipsis:
00260                 return slice1
00261 
00262 ## @brief Completes this slice for a given length.
00263 ##
00264 # The resulting slice will give the same elements for a container of the given length, but
00265 # none of the start, stop, or step attributes will be None. If s is the Ellipses, then 
00266 # the slice (0, length, 1) is returned.
00267 # @deprecated
00268 def complete_slice(s, length):
00269         return s
00270 
00271 ## @brief Sub-classes of this container can be used directly.
00272 ##
00273 ## A principle container will do assignment on a 1D point.
00274 ## Assignment of larger chunks is delegated to the AuxilaryContainer
00275 ## with the right dimensions.
00276 ##
00277 ## The enherritance is merely for documentation purposes.
00278 class PrincipleContainer:
00279         pass
00280 
00281 ## @brief Sub-classes of this container is used as windows by a
00282 ##PrincipleContainer, and should not be used directly!
00283 ##
00284 ## An AuxiliaryContainer will do assignment a chunk with the same 
00285 ## dimensionality as itself, otherwise it delegates it to the underlying
00286 ## principle container, which will, in turn, construct the correct 
00287 ## AuxiliaryContainer to perform the assignment, or perform it if it is 
00288 ## a 1D point.
00289 ##
00290 ## The enherritance is merely for documentation purposes.
00291 class AuxiliaryContainer:
00292         pass
00293 
00294 ##Abstract super class of all grid-like containers.
00295 ##These containers are static, that is, once they are created, 
00296 ##their dimensions cannot change.
00297 #
00298 # Children of this class must implement
00299 # the attribute __clonetype__, which must 
00300 # hold a callable type that can be constructed
00301 # for clones.
00302 # 
00303 # Children must also implement the iterators
00304 # cell_iter() and index_iter().
00305 class Container:
00306         ##
00307         ##
00308         # @param dim
00309         #               The dimensions of this grid
00310         def __init__(self, dims):
00311                 self.dims = dims
00312                 
00313                 count = 1
00314                 
00315                 for dim in dims:
00316                         count *= dim
00317                 
00318                 self.count = count
00319         
00320         ##Test whether two containers have the same dimensions
00321         ##and the same items at equal indices.
00322         def __eq__(self, other):
00323                 if self.dims != other.dims:
00324                         return False
00325                 
00326                 for cell1, cell2 in zip(self.cell_iter(), other.cell_iter()):
00327                         if cell1 != cell2:
00328                                 return False
00329                 return True
00330         
00331         ##Equivalent to @code not (self == other) @endcode .
00332         def __ne__(self, other):
00333                 return not (self == other)
00334                 
00335         ## Returns the length (1D) or width (nD) of this container.
00336         #
00337         # The length of a container is defined such that the length behaves as it would
00338         # for a list of lists.
00339         def __len__(self):
00340                 return self.dims[0]
00341         
00342         ## @brief Returns the minimum and maximum elements
00343         ## of this grid as a tuple. 
00344         ##
00345         #This method assumes the grid is filled.
00346         def min_max(self):              
00347                 cell_iter = self.cell_iter()            
00348                 min = max = cell_iter.next()
00349                 
00350                 for cell in cell_iter:
00351                         if cell > max:
00352                                 max = cell
00353                         elif cell < min:
00354                                 min = cell
00355                 return min, max
00356                 
00357         def copy_from(self, other):
00358                 for index in self.index_iter():
00359                         self[index] = other[index]
00360         
00361         ##Makes a shallow copy of this container.
00362         #
00363         #This method constructs an instance of
00364         #this instance's __clonetype__. In general,
00365         #if this class is an AuxiliaryContainer,
00366         #the clone will be a PrincipleContainer
00367         #of the same dimension.
00368         def clone(self):
00369                 new_grid = self.__clonetype__(self.dims)                
00370                 new_grid.copy_from(self)
00371                 
00372                 return new_grid
00373                 
00374 ## Class that implements __str__ and __iter__.
00375 class Container1D (Container):
00376         def __init__(self, length):
00377                 Container.__init__(self, (length,))
00378                 self.length = length
00379                 self.__clonetype__ = Grid1D
00380                 
00381         def __str__(self):    
00382                 #slow...
00383                 glst = []
00384                 
00385                 for i in range(self.length):
00386                         glst.append(self[i])
00387                         
00388                 return glst.__repr__()
00389         
00390         def __iter__(self):
00391                 for i in range(self.length):
00392                         yield self[i]
00393                 raise StopIteration
00394 
00395         ## @brief Returns the same iterator as __iter__.
00396         #
00397         # Provided so that all containers have consistent cell_iter methods.
00398         def cell_iter(self):
00399                 return self.__iter__()
00400         
00401         ## @brief Returns an iterator that iterates over a subgrid of this grid.
00402         ##
00403         # The iteratir will iterate over all cells x, y in the grid     
00404         # such that 
00405         #@code
00406         # x0 <= x < x1
00407         # y0 <= y < y1
00408         #@endcode
00409         #       
00410         def window_iter(self, p):
00411                 (x0, x1) = p
00412                 for i in range(max(0, x0), min(x1, self.length)):
00413                         yield self[i]
00414                 raise StopIteration
00415         
00416         ## @brief Returns an iterator that iterates over all cells in the square
00417         ## surrounding the given point. 
00418         ##
00419         #The square is 2*n + 1 units.
00420         def square_iter(self, x, n):
00421                 return self.window_iter((x - n, x + n + 1))
00422         
00423         ## @brief Returns an iterator that iterates over the indeces of this 
00424         ## container.
00425         ##
00426         # If grid is a 2 by 2 grid, then:
00427         # @code
00428         # for p in index_iter(grid):
00429         #       print p
00430         # @endcode
00431         # will produce 
00432         # @code
00433         # 0, 0
00434         # 0, 1
00435         # 1, 0
00436         # 1, 1
00437         # @endcode
00438         # This iterator is useful for assigning elements of grids:
00439         # @code
00440         # for p in index_iter(grid):
00441         #       grid[p] = random()
00442         # @endcode
00443         def index_iter(self):
00444                 for i in range(self.length):
00445                         yield i
00446                 raise StopIteration
00447 
00448 ## Class that implements __str__ and __iter__.
00449 class Container2D (Container):
00450         def __init__(self, width, height):
00451                 Container.__init__(self, (width, height))
00452                 self.width = width
00453                 self.height = height
00454                 self.__clonetype__ = Grid2D
00455                 
00456         def __str__(self):    
00457                 #slow...
00458                 glst = []
00459                 
00460                 for i in range(self.width):
00461                         gcol = []
00462                         
00463                         for j in range(self.height):
00464                                 gcol.append(self[i, j])
00465                                 
00466                         glst.append(gcol)
00467                                 
00468                 return glst.__repr__()  
00469                 
00470         ## @brief Returns an iterator that iterates over columns.
00471         ##
00472         # This iterator is provided so that a Grid2D better emulates a list of 
00473         # lists, as in the following example:
00474         #@code
00475         #       for col in grid:
00476         #               for item in col:
00477         #                       process(item)
00478         #@endcode
00479         # Use of this iterator is discouraged - it is slow
00480         def __iter__(self):
00481                 for i in range(self.width):
00482                         yield self[i, ...]
00483                 raise StopIteration
00484 
00485         ## @brief Returns an iterator that iterates over all cells in the grid.
00486         ##
00487         # This allows you to write:
00488         #@code
00489         # for cell in cell_iter(grid):
00490         #   process(cell)
00491         #@endcode
00492         def cell_iter(self):
00493                 for i in range(self.width):
00494                         for j in range(self.height):
00495                                 yield self[i, j]
00496                 raise StopIteration
00497         
00498         ## @brief Returns an iterator that iterates over a subgrid of this grid.
00499         ##
00500         # The iterator will iterate over all cells x, y in the grid     
00501         # such that 
00502         #@code
00503         # x0 <= x < x1
00504         # y0 <= y < y1
00505         #@endcode
00506         #       
00507         def window_iter(self, px, py):
00508                 x0, x1 = px
00509                 y0, y1 = py
00510                 for i in range(max(0, x0), min(x1, self.width)):
00511                         for j in range(max(0, y0), min(y1, self.height)):
00512                                 yield self[i, j]
00513                 raise StopIteration
00514         
00515         ## @brief Returns an iterator that iterates over all cells in the square
00516         ## surrounding the given point. 
00517         ##
00518         #The square is 2*n + 1 units.
00519         def square_iter(self, p, n):
00520                 x, y = p
00521                 return self.window_iter((x - n, x + n + 1), (y - n, y + n +1))
00522         
00523         ## @brief Returns an iterator that iterates over the indeces of this 
00524         ## grid as tuples.
00525         ##
00526         # If grid is a 2 by 2 grid, then:
00527         # @code
00528         # for p in index_iter(grid):
00529         #       print p
00530         # @endcode
00531         # will produce 
00532         # @code
00533         # 0, 0
00534         # 0, 1
00535         # 1, 0
00536         # 1, 1
00537         # @endcode
00538         # This iterator is useful for assigning elements of grids:
00539         # @code
00540         # for p in index_iter(grid):
00541         #       grid[p] = random()
00542         # @endcode
00543         def index_iter(self):
00544                 for i in range(self.width):
00545                         for j in range(self.height):
00546                                 yield i, j
00547                 raise StopIteration
00548 
00549 ## Class that implements __str__ and __iter__.
00550 class Container3D (Container):
00551         def __init__(self, width, height, depth):
00552                 Container.__init__(self, (width, height, depth))
00553                 self.width = width
00554                 self.height = height
00555                 self.depth = depth
00556                 
00557                 self.__clonetype__ = Grid3D
00558                 
00559         def __str__(self):    
00560                 #slow...
00561                 glst = []
00562                 
00563                 for i in range(self.width):
00564                         gcol = []
00565                         for j in range(self.height):
00566                                 gslice = []
00567                                 
00568                                 for k in range(self.depth):
00569                                         gslice.append(self[i, j, k])
00570                                 
00571                                 gcol.append(gslice)
00572                         glst.append(gcol)
00573                                 
00574                 return glst.__repr__()
00575         
00576         def __iter__(self):
00577                 for i in range(self.width):
00578                         yield self[i, ..., ...]
00579                 raise StopIteration
00580 
00581         ## Returns an iterator that iterates over all cells in the grid
00582         def cell_iter(self):
00583                 for i in range(self.width):
00584                         for j in range(self.height):
00585                                 for k in range(self.depth):
00586                                         yield self[i, j, k]
00587                 raise StopIteration
00588                 
00589         ## @brief Returns an iterator that iterates over the indeces of this 
00590         ## grid as tuples.
00591         ##
00592         # If grid is a 2 by 2 grid, then:
00593         # @code
00594         # for p in index_iter(grid):
00595         #       print p
00596         # @endcode
00597         # will produce 
00598         # @code
00599         # 0, 0
00600         # 0, 1
00601         # 1, 0
00602         # 1, 1
00603         # @endcode
00604         # This iterator is useful for assigning elements of grids:
00605         # @code
00606         # for p in index_iter(grid):
00607         #       grid[p] = random()
00608         # @endcode
00609         def index_iter(self):
00610                 for i in range(self.width):
00611                         for j in range(self.height):
00612                                 for k in range (self.depth):
00613                                         yield i, j, k
00614                 raise StopIteration     
00615 
00616         ## @brief Returns an iterator that iterates over a subgrid of this grid.
00617         ##
00618         # The iterator will iterate over all cells x, y, z in the grid
00619         # such that 
00620         #@code
00621         # x0 <= x < x1
00622         # y0 <= y < y1
00623         # z0 <= z < z1
00624         #@endcode
00625         #
00626         def window_iter(self, px, py, pz):
00627                 x0, x1 = px
00628                 y0, y1 = py
00629                 z0, z1 = pz
00630                 for i in range(max(0, x0), min(x1, self.width)):
00631                         for j in range(max(0, y0), min(y1, self.height)):
00632                                 for k in range(max(0, z0), min(z1, self.depth)):
00633                                         yield self[i, j, k]
00634                 raise StopIteration
00635 
00636         ## @brief Returns an iterator that iterates over all cells in the square
00637         ##      surrounding the given point. 
00638         ##
00639         #The cube is 2*n + 1 units.
00640         def square_iter(self, p, n):
00641                 x, y, z = p
00642                 return self.window_iter(
00643                         (x - n, x + n + 1), 
00644                         (y - n, y + n +1),
00645                         (z - n, z + n +1))
00646 
00647 class GridWindow1D (Container1D, AuxiliaryContainer): #Constant y
00648         def __init__(self, grid, col_slice):
00649                 self.grid = grid
00650                 self.x = complete_slice(col_slice, grid.width)          
00651                 Container1D.__init__(self, slice_len(self.x), grid.width)
00652         
00653         def __getitem__(self, x):
00654                 new_x = slice_mul(self.x, x, self.grid.width)
00655                 
00656                 return self.grid[new_x]         
00657                 
00658         def __setitem__(self, x, item):
00659                 new_x = slice_mul(self.x, x, self.grid.width)
00660                 
00661                 if type(x) is int:
00662                         self.grid[new_x] = item
00663                 else: #slice!
00664                         for i, item_i in zip(srange(new_x, self.grid.width), item):
00665                                 self.grid[i] = item_i
00666 
00667 ## Class that represent a 2D grid, with enhanced slicing notation.
00668 class Grid1D (Container1D, PrincipleContainer):
00669         def __init__(self, dims, initial_item = None):
00670                 (width,) = dims
00671                 Container1D.__init__(self, width)
00672                 self.grid = make_grid_1d(width, initial_item)
00673                 self.width = width
00674         ## @brief Returns an iterator that iterates over all cells in the grid.
00675         ##
00676         # This allows you to write:
00677         #@code
00678         # for cell in cell_iter(grid):
00679         #   process(cell)
00680         #@endcode
00681         def cell_iter(self):
00682                 for i in range(self.width):
00683                         yield self.grid[i]
00684                 raise StopIteration
00685                 
00686         def __getitem__(self, x):
00687                 if isinstance(x, int):
00688                         return self.grid[x]
00689                 elif is_slice(x):
00690                         GridWindow1D(self, x)
00691                 raise TypeError
00692 
00693         def __setitem__(self, x, item):         
00694                 if type(x) is int:                      
00695                         self.grid[x] = item
00696                 elif is_slice(x):
00697                         g = GridWindow1D(self, x)
00698                         g[...] = item
00699                 else:
00700                         raise TypeError
00701 
00702 class GridRow2D (Container1D, AuxiliaryContainer): #Constant y
00703         def __init__(self, grid, col_slice, row):
00704                 self.grid = grid
00705                 self.x = complete_slice(col_slice, grid.width)
00706                 self.y = row
00707                 
00708                 Container1D.__init__(self, slice_len(self.x, grid.width))
00709         
00710         def __getitem__(self, x):
00711                 new_x = slice_mul(self.x, x, self.grid.width)
00712                 
00713                 return self.grid[new_x, self.y]         
00714                 
00715         def __setitem__(self, x, item):
00716                 new_x = slice_mul(self.x, x, self.grid.width)
00717                 
00718                 if type(x) is int:
00719                         self.grid[new_x] = item
00720                 else: #slice!
00721                         for i, item_i in zip(srange(new_x, self.grid.width), item):
00722                                 self.grid[i, self.y] = item_i

00724 class GridCol2D (Container1D, AuxiliaryContainer): #Constant x
00725         def __init__(self, grid, col, row_slice):
00726                 self.grid = grid
00727                 self.x = col
00728                 self.y = complete_slice(row_slice, grid.height)
00729                 
00730                 Container1D.__init__(self, slice_len(self.y, grid.height))
00731         
00732         def __getitem__(self,  y):
00733                 new_y = slice_mul(self.y, y, self.grid.height)
00734                 
00735                 return self.grid[self.x, new_y]
00736                 
00737         def __setitem__(self, y, item):
00738                 new_y = slice_mul(self.y, y, self.grid.height)
00739                 
00740                 if type(y) is int:                      
00741                         self.grid[self.x, new_y] = item
00742                 else: #slice!
00743                         for i, item_i in zip(srange(new_y, self.grid.height), item):
00744                                 self.grid[self.x, i] = item_i

00746 class GridWindow2D (Container2D):
00747         def __init__(self, grid, x, y):
00748                 self.grid = grid
00749                 self.x = complete_slice(x, grid.width)
00750                 self.y = complete_slice(y, grid.height)
00751                 
00752                 Container2D.__init__(self, slice_len(self.x, grid.width), slice_len(self.y, grid.height))
00753                                                 
00754         def __getitem__(self, p):
00755                 if isinstance(p, int):
00756                         return self[p, ...]                     
00757                 x, y = p                        
00758                 
00759                 new_x = slice_mul(self.x, x, self.grid.width)
00760                 new_y = slice_mul(self.y, y, self.grid.height)
00761                 return self.grid[new_x, new_y]
00762                 
00763         def __setitem__(self, p, item):
00764                 if isinstance(p, int):
00765                         self[p, ...] = item
00766                 x, y = p
00767                 new_x = slice_mul(self.x, x, self.grid.width)
00768                 new_y = slice_mul(self.y, y, self.grid.height)
00769                 
00770                 if type(x) is int or type(y) is int:
00771                         #delegate!                      
00772                         self.grid[new_x, new_y] = item
00773                 else: #slice!
00774                         for i, item_i in zip(srange(new_x, self.grid.width), item):
00775                                 for j, item_j in zip(srange(new_y, self.grid.height), item_i):
00776                                         self.grid[i, j] = item_j
00777         
00778         def __repr__(self):    
00779                 #slow...
00780                 glst = []
00781                 
00782                 for i in range(slice_len(self.x, self.grid.width)):
00783                         gcol = []
00784                         for j in range(slice_len(self.y, self.grid.height)):
00785                                 gcol.append(self[i, j])
00786                         glst.append(gcol)
00787                                 
00788                 return glst.__repr__()                  
00789 
00790 ## Class that represent a 2D grid, with enhanced slicing notation.
00791 class Grid2D (Container2D, PrincipleContainer):
00792         
00793         def __init__(self, dims, initial_item = None):
00794                 (width, height) = dims
00795                 Container2D.__init__(self, width, height)
00796                 self.grid = make_grid_2d(width, height, initial_item)
00797         ## @brief Returns an iterator that iterates over all cells in the grid.
00798         ##
00799         # This allows you to write:
00800         #@code
00801         # for cell in cell_iter(grid):
00802         #   process(cell)
00803         #@endcode
00804         def cell_iter(self):
00805                 for i in range(self.width):
00806                         for j in range(self.height):
00807                                 yield self.grid[i][j]
00808                 raise StopIteration
00809                 
00810         def __getitem__(self, p):
00811                 if isinstance(p, int):
00812                         return self[p, ...]
00813                 x, y = p
00814                 if isinstance(x, int):
00815                         if isinstance(y, int):
00816                                 return self.grid[x][y]
00817                         elif is_slice(y):
00818                                 return GridCol2D(self, x, y)
00819                 elif is_slice(x):
00820                         if isinstance(y, int):
00821                                 return GridRow2D(self, x, y)
00822                         elif is_slice(y):
00823                                 return GridWindow2D(self, x, y)
00824                 
00825                 raise TypeError
00826 
00827         def __setitem__(self, p, item):         
00828                 x, y = p
00829                 if type(x) is int:
00830                         if type(y) is int:
00831                                 self.grid[x][y] = item
00832                         elif is_slice(y):
00833                                 g = GridCol2D(self, x, y)
00834                                 g[...] = item
00835                 elif is_slice(x):
00836                         if type(y) is int:
00837                                 g = GridRow2D(self, x, y)
00838                                 g[...] = item
00839                         elif is_slice(y):
00840                                 g = GridWindow2D(self, x, y)
00841                                 g[..., ...] = item
00842                 else:
00843                         raise TypeError
00844

00908 class GridSliceXY (Container2D, AuxiliaryContainer): #constant z
00909         def __init__(self, grid, x, y, z):
00910                 self.grid = grid
00911                 self.x = complete_slice(x, grid.width)
00912                 self.y = complete_slice(y, grid.height)
00913                 self.z = z              
00914                 Container2D.__init__(self, slice_len(self.x, grid.width), slice_len(self.y, grid.height))
00915         def __getitem__(self,  p):
00916                 if isinstance(p, int):
00917                         return self[p, ...]                     
00918                 x, y = p        
00919                 new_x = slice_mul(self.x, x, self.grid.width)           
00920                 new_y = slice_mul(self.y, y, self.grid.height)
00921                 return self.grid[new_x, new_y, self.z]
00922         
00923         def __setitem__(self, p, item):
00924                 if isinstance(p, int):
00925                         self[p, ...] = item
00926                 x, y = p        
00927                 new_x = slice_mul(self.x, x, self.grid.width)
00928                 new_y = slice_mul(self.y, y, self.grid.height)
00929                 
00930                 if type(x) is int or type(y) is int:
00931                         #delegate!
00932                         self.grid[new_x, new_y, self.z] = item
00933                 else: #slice!
00934                         for i, item_i in zip(srange(new_x, self.grid.width), item):
00935                                 for j, item_j in zip(srange(new_y, self.grid.height), item_i):
00936                                         self.grid[i, j, self.z] = item_j

01000 class GridWindow3D (Container3D, AuxiliaryContainer):
01001         def __init__(self, grid, x, y, z):
01002                 self.grid = grid
01003                 self.x = complete_slice(x, grid.width)
01004                 self.y = complete_slice(y, grid.height)
01005                 self.z = complete_slice(z, grid.height) 
01006                 
01007                 Container3D.__init__(self, slice_len(self.x, grid.width), slice_len(self.y, grid.height), slice_len(self.z, grid.depth))
01008         def __getitem__(self, p):
01009                 if isinstance(p, int):
01010                         return self[p, ..., ...]                        
01011                 x, y, z = p     
01012                 new_x = slice_mul(self.x, x, self.grid.width)
01013                 new_y = slice_mul(self.y, y, self.grid.height)
01014                 new_z = slice_mul(self.z, z, self.grid.depth)
01015                 
01016                 return self.grid[new_x, new_y, new_z]
01017         
01018         def __setitem__(self, p, item):
01019                 if isinstance(p, int):
01020                         self[p, ..., ...] = item
01021                 x, y, z = p     
01022                 new_x = slice_mul(self.x, x, self.grid.width)
01023                 new_y = slice_mul(self.y, y, self.grid.height)
01024                 new_z = slice_mul(self.z, z, self.grid.depth)
01025                 
01026                 if type(x) is int or type(y) is int or type(z) is int:
01027                         #delegate!
01028                         self.grid[new_x, new_y, self.z] = item
01029                 else: #slice!
01030                         for i, item_i in zip(srange(new_x, self.grid.width), item):
01031                                 for j, item_j in zip(srange(new_y, self.grid.height), item_i):
01032                                         for k, item_k in zip(srange(new_z, self.grid.depth), item_j):
01033                                                 self.grid[i, j, k] = item_k

01035 ## Class that represent a 3D grid, with enhanced slicing notation.
01036 class Grid3D (Container3D, PrincipleContainer):
01037         def __init__(self, dims, initial_item = None):
01038                 (width, height, depth) = dims
01039                 Container3D.__init__(self, width, height, depth)
01040                 self.grid = make_grid_3d(width, height, depth, initial_item)
01041                 
01042         def __getitem__(self, p):
01043                 if isinstance(p, int):
01044                         return self[p, ..., ...]
01045                 x, y, z = p
01046                 if type(x) is int:
01047                         if type(y) is int:
01048                                 if type(z) is int:
01049                                         return self.grid[x][y][z]
01050                                 elif is_slice(z):
01051                                         return GridBar3D(self, x, y, z)
01052                         elif is_slice(y):
01053                                 if type(z) is int:
01054                                         return GridCol3D(self, x, y, z)
01055                                 elif is_slice(z):
01056                                         return GridSliceYZ(self, x, y, z)
01057                 elif is_slice(x):
01058                         if type(y) is int:
01059                                 if type(z) is int:
01060                                         return GridRow3D(self, x, y, z)
01061                                 elif is_slice(z):
01062                                         return GridSliceXZ(self, x, y, z)
01063                         elif is_slice(y):
01064                                 if type(z) is int:
01065                                         return GridSliceXY(self, x, y, z)
01066                                 elif is_slice(z):
01067                                         return GridWindow3D(self, x, y, z)
01068                 
01069                 raise TypeError
01070                 
01071         def __setitem__(self, p, item):
01072                 (x, y, z) = p
01073                 if type(x) is int:
01074                         if type(y) is int:
01075                                 if type(z) is int:
01076                                         self.grid[x][y][z] = item
01077                                 elif is_slice(z):
01078                                         g = GridBar3D(self, x, y, z)
01079                                         g[...] = item
01080                         elif is_slice(y):
01081                                 if type(z) is int:
01082                                         g = GridCol3D(self, x, y, z)
01083                                         g[...] = item
01084                                 elif is_slice(z):
01085                                         g = GridSliceYZ(self, x, y, z)
01086                                         g[..., ...] = item
01087                 elif is_slice(x):
01088                         if type(y) is int:
01089                                 if type(z) is int:
01090                                         g = GridRow3D(self, x, y, z)
01091                                         g[...] = item
01092                                 elif is_slice(z):
01093                                         g = GridSliceXZ(self, x, y, z)
01094                                         g[..., ...] = item
01095                         elif is_slice(y):
01096                                 if type(z) is int:
01097                                         g = GridSliceXY(self, x, y, z)
01098                                         g[..., ...] = item
01099                                 elif is_slice(z):
01100                                         g = GridWindow3D(self, x, y, z)
01101                                         g[..., ..., ...] = item
01102                 else:
01103                         raise TypeError

01105 class ListGrid3D (Grid3D):
01106         def __init__(self, dims):
01107                 (width, height, depth) = dims
01108                 Grid3D.__init__(self, (width, height, depth))
01109         
01110                 for index in self.index_iter():
01111                         self[index] = []
01112 
01113         ## @brief Sets the item at x, y.
01114         ##
01115         # Use a tuplet (x, y) to access the item.
01116         def additem(self, p, b):
01117                 (x, y, z) = p
01118                 self[x, y, z].append(b)
01119                         
01120 class ListGrid2D (Grid2D):

01122                 (width, height) = dims
01123                 Grid2D.__init__(self, (width, height))
01124         
01125                 for index in self.index_iter():
01126                         self[index] = []

01128         ## @brief Sets the item at x, y.
01129         ##
01130         # Use a tuplet (x, y) to access the item.
01131         def additem(self, p, b):
01132                 (x, y) = p
01133                 self[x, y].append(b)
